maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by by Manuscript Division staff.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Comedy writer and political speechwriter. Correspondence, jokes and other writings, business papers, photographs, printed matter, interviews, and speeches in both physical and digital formats pertaining to Orben's work as a comedy writer and humor consultant for entertainers, public figures, and corporate clients, editor of a topical humor service, writer for television, and speechwriter for President Gerald R. Ford.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Robert Orben were given to the Library of Congress by Orben in 2019.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Robert Orben were arranged and described by Laura J. Kells between 2019 and 2021.

Digital files were received as part of the Robert Orben Papers on a variety of storage media, each of which was assigned a unique digital ID number. Use the digital ID number to request access copies of the files associated with each media. A description of the standard processes taken on all born digital records can be found in the Processing History Note: Born Digital Collection Material at https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mss/eadmss.digital.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Some audio and video tapes have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of the Robert Orben Papers. Patrons are encouraged to contact the Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division in advance of a research visit.

separatedmaterial.head: Other Repositories
separatedmaterial.p: Other papers of Robert Orben can be found in the Gerald R. Ford Library, Ann Arbor, Mich.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Robert Orben in these papers and in other collections of papers in the custody of the Library of Congress has been dedicated to the public.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Robert Orben are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Digital files are audio files (.wav), PowerPoint 97 and 2016 presentation files (.ppt), and video files (.vob).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or digital ID number, Robert Orben Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Robert Orben (1927-2023) span the dates 1941-2019. The collection documents Orben's career as a comedy writer and humor consultant, and speechwriter for President Gerald R. Ford. The papers are arranged into five series: General Correspondence, Alphabetical File, Speeches and Writings, Miscellany, and Oversize.

This collection documents Orben's work as a comedy writer and promoter of humor. Orben initially focused on magic and magicians, but over time expanded his reach and wrote material for use by a wide range of performers and public speakers. A strength of this collection is the compilation of jokes and one-liners he wrote over the second half of the twentieth century, that he published under his own name, prepared for other performers, created for The Red Skelton Hour television program, and supplied for corporate events. His periodical, Orben's Current Comedy , a topical subscription service, contains jokes relating to the public figures, cultural trends, and current events from 1958 to 1989. A smaller amount of similar material from the 1990s that he sent to columnists and others is dispersed throughout collection. Orben's work as a promoter of and advisor on the use of humor in public speaking and his life-long connection to magicians and the magic profession are also documented. The collection complements a larger collection of Robert Orben Papers at the Gerald R. Ford Library in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Material pertaining to Orben's time as a speechwriter in the Ford White House includes memorabilia, photographs, an oral history transcript, speeches, and an unpublished memoir.
The collection's series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within the container list.
The General Correspondence series comprises a chronological grouping of letters sent and received by Orben between the years 1963 and 2019.
The Alphabetical File series touches on all aspects of his career and documents Orben’s dealings with colleagues, publishers, publications, organizations, columnists, clients, and friends.

The Speeches and Writings series contains approximately sixty years of jokes, one-liners, writings, and remarks from Orben's career as a comedy writer and humor consultant for performers, television programs, public figures, and corporate clients.
A small Miscellany series contains additional material documenting Orben's life and career including press clippings and photographs depicting his work with President Gerald R. Ford.
The remaining series contains Oversize material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in five series:

scopecontent.p: The General Correspondence series comprises a chronological grouping of letters sent and received by Orben between the years 1963 and 2019. The letters date from the period that Orben moved to California to work as a writer for the television program, The Red Skelton Hour , and continue into his retirement years. While some of the correspondence relates to his work, much of it is of a personal nature. Additional correspondence, grouped alphabetically by name of correspondent or topic, is located in the Alphabetical File series.
Material types include letters sent and received with related attachments. One attachment is in digital format as a PowerPoint presentation.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

did.didnote: Attachments to correspondence included storage media described below.

did.unittitle: 2019, Nilsen, Alleen Pace, and Don L. F. Nilsen, The Language of Humor , PowerPoint presentation

scopecontent.p: The Alphabetical File series touches on all aspects of his career and documents Orben’s dealings with colleagues, publishers, publications, organizations, columnists, clients, and friends. Files relating to Orben’s business partner in the 1960s, Stanley Kupferman, contain their extensive correspondence from when Orben was in California containing details about their business, Orben Publications, and their efforts to promote and sell Orben’s books and other comedy products. Orben’s letters to Kupferman also describe his experience as a writer for The Red Skelton Hour and touch on his work for comedian Dick Gregory. A large portion of this material dates from the years after Orben’s work for President Gerald R. Ford. Items relating to Gerald R. Ford include letters from Ford documenting Orben’s continued assistance with speeches in the years following his presidency and memorabilia from Orben’s time in the Ford White House.
Material types include correspondence, business papers, printed matter, and one-liners and other humorous material Orben sent to individuals and publications.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name or topic. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: The Speeches and Writings series contains approximately sixty years of jokes, one-liners, writings, and remarks from Orben's career as a comedy writer and humor consultant for performers, television programs, public figures, and corporate clients. His earliest material is included in a grouping of small self-published books, such as The Encyclopedia of Patter (1946), Magicdotes (1948), and The Working Comedian’s Gag File (1956), that Orben wrote for magicians, emcees, comedians, and other performers. The largest portion of this material relates to his topical humor service, Orben’s Current Comedy , that he edited from 1958 to 1989 with a small break between 1968 and 1971. This periodical, issued monthly and then bi-monthly, contains jokes and one-liners relating to current events and prominent figures in politics and entertainment. Orben later compiled some of this material into a series of books. Orben’s writing for television is documented in an index card file arranged by topic, labeled “Skelton Stockpile,” containing jokes he wrote for The Red Skelton Hour as well material he wrote for The Jack Paar Program in 1962. Another set of index cards contains material Orben wrote for comedian Dick Gregory’s book, From the Back of the Bus (1962). Additional material relating to this project can be found in the Alphabetical File series. Another group of writings contains material he wrote for International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) corporate events. Orben’s articles and essays about the writing, effective delivery, and use of humor in speeches, as well as his speeches and speech material about humor in the presidency are also included in this series. An unpublished memoir offers Orben’s account of events in his life until the end of his time in the Gerald R. Ford administration. Additional jokes that he sent to individuals and publications, particularly topical material written in the 1990s, are located in the Alphabetical File series under the name of the person or publication.
Material types include jokes, articles, books, book drafts, periodicals, a memoir, notes, interview transcripts, speeches, and scripts.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title or type of material and therein chronologically. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: A small Miscellany series contains additional material documenting Orben's life and career including press clippings about or mentioning him and photographs depicting his work with President Gerald R. Ford. A scrapbook contains Orben's earliest published writings, most of which relate to magic.
Material types include card files, calendars, photographs, press clippings, lists, passports, a scrapbook, and video files from an award ceremony.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material or name. The file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: Card files of jokes, card files of addresses, photographs, a proclamation, and a scrapbook.

arrangement.p: Listed and described according to the series, containers, and folders from which the material was separated. The items are physically grouped and arranged by size.
